conclusion: Analyzing the charged particle motion in the magnetic fields

The setup includes two uniform magnetic field regions separated by a gap, a thin insulating plate ab of length 4d positioned in the gap, a positively charged particle injected at point c with velocity v₀ at 45° angle, after collision with the plate, velocity components change as described, particle finally exits at point f, which is 2d away from c horizontally
Analyze the particle motion through different regions
When a charged particle enters a magnetic field, it experiences a force causing circular motion with radius r = mv/qB
The initial velocity has components v₀ₓ = v₀/√2 and v₀ᵧ = v₀/√2
In a uniform magnetic field, the particle follows a circular path with radius r = mv₀/(qB)
When the particle collides with the insulating plate, the vertical component remains unchanged and the horizontal component reverses direction but keeps the same magnitude
After collision, the particle re-enters the magnetic field region with a modified velocity, and the circular motion will be in the opposite direction
For the particle to exit at point f, which is 2d away from c horizontally and at the same vertical level as b, we need to determine what magnetic field strength would create this exact path
The particle starts at c with velocity at 45°, follows a circular path until hitting the plate, and after collision, follows another circular path until reaching f
For a circular path with radius r = mv₀/(qB), the particle will travel along an arc, and for it to reach point f, the magnetic field B must be precisely tuned
The radius of the arcs must be related to the distances in the problem, and for the particle to exit at point f, the radius must be exactly r = 2d
Since r = mv₀/(qB), solve for B: B = mv₀/(2qd)
The magnitude of the magnetic induction B is B = mv₀/(2qd)
